- Constructing and modernizing 21st century classrooms, restrooms and facilities,

- Improving student access to computers and modern technology, and

Dear Black Oak Mine Families,

Per our latest update, PG&E will announce the "all-clear" between 6:00 and 8:00 am tomorrow morning. This means they will begin to inspect lines, with power to be restored in 24-48 hours from the time of the all-clear. It is clear we will not have power for schools tomorrow. As a result, all schools in the Black Oak Mine Unified School District are closed tomorrow, October 28th. Georgetown, however, will maintain its schedule of parent/teacher conferences.

We will wait for additional updates with regard to Tuesday and will update you as we have additional information. As previously mentioned, we will communicate with families next week regarding our various options for days missed, to date.

We hope you are all doing well under the circumstances. Our thoughts and prayers are with those currently under threat from forest fires.

Again, we will update as we have additional information. Thank you for your patience as we work through these unprecedented challenges.

Thank you and have a nice evening.

Jeremy.

UPDATE: Power is back on at ARCS, GT, Divide and the District Office. GT and ARCS will still be on a 2-hr delayed start, including transportation.

Dear Black Oak Mine Families,

ARCS, GT, Divide, and the District Office remain without power. Northside never lost power and Golden Sierra now has power. We are opening the District tomorrow - ALL SCHOOLS WILL BE OPEN AND OPERATING. GT, and ARCS will be on a 2-hour delayed start, including transportation, with or without power. We are optimistic that all sights will have power in the am tomorrow.

These are very difficult decisions to make and, on balance, we believe this is the right thing to do.

Again, all schools are operational tomorrow - GT and ARCS will be on a 2-hour delayed start, including transportation, with or without power. We greatly appreciate your patience and flexibility - we had hoped to have power at all sites this evening.

Thanks,

Jeremy

I wish to express my gratitude to the good people on The Divide. Rob and I left two and a half years ago and moved to Paradise. Of course two months ago that has all changed. The sudden loss of home and community has resulted in a grieving process that continues to this day. That being said, the loving gestures of friends and strangers alike has been a healing balm to our hearts and souls. Thank you Divide people for your generous, thoughtful outreach to Paradise and to us personally. Special mention to the yoga community led by Traci Williamson Preble and Lynette Baugh Masztakowski, Jill at Cool Massage, the sweet women at Drug Free Divide, the kind souls from Black Oak Mine School District, the Calvary Chapel Georgetown Shawl Ministry, and the countless individuals- you know who you are. Please know that your words of love and encouragement and the thoughtful gifts are indelibly inscribed in our hearts and souls. Thank you, Lori and Rob Williams.

post_text: Good evening Black Oak Mine Families. This is Jeremy Meyers, Superintendent/Principal. As a District, we are closely monitoring the air quality. Clearly, it is poor in each of our communities. As such, we are adjusting our activities. PE, recess, and practices are being held in doors. Additionally, we are frequently replacing our air filters. School nurses are routinely monitoring students with known respiratory issues. Simply put, we are doing what can be done to limit student exposure to outside smoke. In the meantime, our thoughts and prayers are with the families most directly impacted by these devastating fires. As a reminder, our website posts a link for you to provide support. We will update you as conditions change our response. Thank you and have a nice evening.

The road is about to get crowded again with buses getting ready to hit the streets for back to school. Even with the risk of being caught, some drivers still illegally pass a stopped bus when children are loading and unloading.

Confused about when to stop for school buses?

Do not pass a school bus with its flashing red lights and stop sign extended in either direction on an undivided highway. If multiple-lane or divided highway, stop if traveling in the same direction as the bus. Let's work to keep our children safe!
